awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Phytoliths, Starch Grains, and Emerging Social Complexity at Tell Zeidan, Syria
awd_abstract_narration:
Under the guidance of Dr. Alexia Smith, Thomas Hart will analyze ancient plant remains gathered during the 2009 and 2010 excavation seasons at the Ubaid period site of Tell Zeidan, Syria. Tell Zeidan is located at the confluence of the Balikh and Euphrates Rivers and served as a regional center in northern Mesopotamia between 6,000 and 3,800 B. C. The site is of particular importance because it is one of the largest settlements outside of the southern Mesopotamia heartland. In addition, since it was continuously occupied for over 2000 years, it provides a unique opportunity to study one of the earliest developments of social complexity. Mr. Hart's research will use new archaeological techniques, such as phytolith and starch grain analysis, to determine the subsistence practices that made the transition to complex society possible.

The importance of agriculture in facilitating the rise and spread of complex societies is widely accepted. However, with a few exceptions, very little is actually known about subsistence practices in Greater Mesopotamia (the Tigris-Euphrates watershed) between the 6th and 4th millennia B. C. Knowledge of food production and consumption patterns before, during, and after the development of complex societies is essential for revealing the role, if any, of agriculture in emerging social complexity. This project will assess and document each stage of plant food production and consumption from the Ubaid period at Tell Zeidan by examining microscopic plant remains (phytoliths and starch grains) found in archaeological soils, artifact residues, human teeth residues, and the soils associated with the stomach contents of buried individuals. Likewise, by using microscopic remains to reconstruct production and consumption patterns, this project will explore new ways to identify previously invisible markers of social complexity in the archaeological record. When combined with other types of data as part of a larger intra-site study, such as geographic information system data, charred seeds, animal bones, and stone tool data, this project will provide a truly holistic picture of the subsistence practices facilitating the rise of complex society.

This research will seek to have a broader impact beyond the research topics presented. The intra-site study component of this project will foster international collaboration between Syrian researchers and researchers from other universities in Europe and within the U.S. The results from this project will be disseminated in peer-reviewed publications while the raw data will be distributed online thereby making the data available for public use. Public outreach efforts in The United States will include public lectures at the Connecticut State Museum of Natural History and workshops on early agriculture and complex society at the Nonnewaug High School, Woodbury, Connecticut. These efforts will seek to improve public understanding of science, archaeology, and anthropology. Finally, this research hopes to facilitate future research in the sciences by improving the Archaeobotany Laboratory at the University of Connecticut and by training undergraduate research assistants in the skills necessary for scientific research and analysis in this field.

por.por_cntn:
The Ubaid period (6th millennium B.C.) provides an opportunity to explore the relationship between the development of social complexity and agriculture in one of social complexities’ earliest forms. This study is the first of its kind to use microscopic plant remains called phytoliths and starch grains to reconstruct plant use practices associated with early agriculture at one of the largest Ubaid period settlements in Northern Mesopotamia: Tell Zeidan, Syria. This study is divided into four different projects designed to reconstruct subsistence practices at Tell Zeidan. The first two projects involved the analysis of phytolith and starch grains from previously unstudied plant taxa that may have been used at Tell Zeidan. These projects revealed new ways of identifying these species in the archaeological record and addressed the promise, and limitations of using these plant microfossils to reconstruct plant use practices at the site as well as their use as archaeological tools in Southwest Asia. Ten out of 64 species that were analyzed for starch content produced starch grains in large enough quantities to be identified archaeologically. These species included Cyperus esculentus, Vicia ervilia, Moringa peregrina, Pennisetum americanum, Aegilops crassa, Aegilops triaristata, Aegilops vavilovii, Hordeum distichon, Triticum durum, and Triticum compactum. Eleven out of the 181 taxa examined in this project produced phytoliths with phytoliths from the leaves of Ficus retusa leaves holding the most diagnostic potential. These eleven taxa came from the Boraginaceae, Euphorbiaceae, Malvaceae, Moraceae, and Ranunculaceae families.

In the third project, sixteen sediment samples from domestic contexts from the site were studied in order to reconstruct plant use practices. Phytoliths were recovered from the sediments of domestic contexts from the northeastern section of Tell Zeidan and revealed that the inhabitants in the northern section were processing cereals in their domestic structures and disposing of the crop byproducts in trash pits. Wild grasses as well as wheat and barley were being used at Tell Zeidan and were often found as a component of a waste deposit outside of the domestic contexts and in ash dumps inside the domestic contexts. The inhabitants were also using wood and local wetland resources potentially as an additional source of fuel as well as basic building materials. Grasses may also have played a role in ritual at Tell Zeidan in which they were included in both the infant burial and the offering under the mudbrick wall.

The last project involved a preliminary analysis of dental calculus from four individuals from the Halaf, Ubaid, and Late Chalcolithic 2 periods recovered from the cemetery section of Tell Zeidan. Recovery of phytoliths, calcium spherulites, pollen, charcoal, and fungi from the plaque of these individuals demonstrated the feasibility of using dental calculus studies at the site to better understand agriculture and subsistence practices and revealed the potential for exploring previously undetectable behaviors such as the use of dung ash as a dental hygiene product or the consumption of cooked internal meats. While little information was obtained in this study regarding food production patterns that could be used to explore agriculture and emerging complexity, this project has laid the groundwork necessary for exploring these important topics in future samples from Tell Zeidan and at other important Ubaid period settlements in the region.
